repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

Most of the API functions accept optional arguments under a `Dict(<opts>) *opts` whose contents can be statically checked at compile time, *except* for a few functions that still take a `Dictionary opts`. These functions are:

- [x] `nvim_buf_attach`
- [x] `nvim_buf_delete`
- [x] `nvim_buf_get_extmark_by_id`
- [x] `nvim_buf_get_text`
- [x] `nvim_buf_set_mark`
- [x]  `nvim_buf_set_virtual_text`
- [x] `nvim_get_mark`
- [ ] `nvim_notify` (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26365#discussion_r1414705427)
- [x] `nvim_open_term`
- [x] `nvim_parse_cmd`
- [x] `nvim_select_popupmenu_item`

### Solution

Refactor the remaining functions to accept `Dict(<opts>) *opts`.

cc @bfredl @lewis6991

comment_data.body: Minor nitpick (and some guideline), `buf_delete_opts` is a better name for the keyset imo. Generally, I think you can just name the keyset by removing the `nvim_` part from the API function name, that works in most cases.
Removing `nvim_` gets you `buf_delete`, without the `_opts`. None of the current keysets have a trailing `_opts`, except for `cmd_opts`, `echo_opts`, and `exec_opts`.
Renamed to `Dict(buf_delete)`.
these both default to `false` so the assignments can be done directly without HAS_KEY() check
and in cases it should default to true, use `hl_name = GET_BOOL_OR_TRUE(opts, get_extmark, hl_name)`
Added `Dict(empty)` in dca9ba4afdefb1dc19ec7105498a2ae261c7e3de.
Fixed in 686eeb58f79ae6201d9b3fd7426727ee897e53d6.
Fixed in 67f1fa8940ed14bdcf221383b6033c9391b93d77.
This is not backward-compatible.
Technically, taking a keydict at all in this case shouldn't be backwards compatible since it eliminates all keys in this case, correct me if I'm wrong.
Yes. All changes to `nvim_notify` in this PR should be reverted, otherwise it will break plugins that override `vim.notify()`.

It'd break plugins that use `vim.notify` through `nvim_notify` and expect those to be completely equivalent. Is that the case? `nvim_notify`'s docs explicitly say that the `opts` field is `reserved for future use`. If `nvim_notify` must always have the same behavior as `vim.notify` then why have it at all?
IDK. Maybe to make it easier to use from Vimscript? They were added in the same PR #13843.
I think it should be c)
I've reverted all the changes related to `nvim_notify` in 910da65e49fc186d47c3629a81fede3c17c5b6ca. I'll update the docs in a follow-up PR.
Fixed in af08794ed29ae67c508d54e9d97b5341daec2892.
Fixed in af08794ed29ae67c508d54e9d97b5341daec2892.
Fixed in af08794ed29ae67c508d54e9d97b5341daec2892.

comment_regular_data.body:
> @famiu it's deprecated.

Sure but is there any reason not to change it? Refactors can be done on deprecated parts of the code too
No reason not to change it if it's not against the policy for deprecated stuff. Added the refactor in 87726717dcbe4986f6a7e7ea9259335ba0690d57.
I believe the failing tests are flaky and unrelated to the PR. [89a9625](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26365/commits/89a9625e978496ccebf86f1e988ac0337ef2f456) was green.
Otherwise LGTM, thanks for completing this change.
Isn't it easier to review with one commit per function?
Squashed all the commits into c21af375b2f04de680908e1e384b2d8686f29162.

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(api): complete conversion from `Dictionary` to `Dict(opts)`
